name: WebRTC DAT
description: A WebRTC DAT represents a peer on one end of any number of WebRTC peer-to-peer connections.
summary: A WebRTC DAT represents a peer on one end of any number of WebRTC peer-to-peer connections.

parameters.name: Active
parameters.label: Active
parameters.description:
From Derivative
		
		
		
		
		Jump to navigation
		Jump to search
		
A WebRTC  represents a peer on one end of any number of WebRTC peer-to-peer connections.
Each connection is represented in TouchDesigner by a generated UUID. The UUID must be passed to WebrtcDAT Class connection-level python methods.
The WebRTC  output is a table formatted with a row per connection, with columns: id (ie. UUID), connection_state, signaling_state, ice_connection_state, and ice_gathering_state. 
The columns altogether describe the state of a connection and can also be useful for debugging. For example, if ice_connection_state failed then that means there's an issue pairing local and remote ICE candidates for streaming over the network. It could be that NAT traversal failed, and if using a STUN server that might indicate a need for a TURN server (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/STUN#Limitations).
WebRTC video and audio input/output is done via the Video Stream In TOP, Video Stream Out TOP, Audio Stream In CHOP, and Audio Stream Out CHOP.
See also WebRTC.
webrtcDAT_Class

Contents
 
 
 
 




  active - When active, can connect to peers and send media/data. When deactivated, all existing connections will be closed.



  reset - Resets the peer associated with the . Equivalent to deactivating then reactivating the active parameter.



  bitratelimits - When enabled, custom min/max bit rates can be specified. These max bit rate limits are expressed in kbps and apply to all tracks associated with the WebRTC .



  minbitrate - Minimum bit rate for all tracks associated with the WebRTC .



  maxbitrate - Maximum bit rate for all tracks associated with the WebRTC .



  callbacks -  to a  containing WebRTC callbacks.





  stun - URL of the STUN server. See WebRTC#ICE for more details regarding STUN.



  username - Username for access to the specified TURN servers.



  password - Password for access to the specified TURN servers.



  turn - Sequence of TURN server urls.



  turn0server - URL of the TURN server. See WebRTC#ICE for more details regarding TURN.






  language -  - Select how the  decides which script language to operate on.

 input - The  uses the inputs script language. node - The  uses it's own script language.

  extension -  - Select the file extension this  should expose to external editors.

 dat - various common file extensions. frag - glsl - html - md - py - rtf - tsv - txt - vert - xml - languageext - pick extension from DATs script language. customext - Specify a custom extension.

  customext - Specifiy the custom extension.



  wordwrap -  - Enable Word Wrap for Node Display.

 input - The  uses the inputs setting. on - Turn on Word Wrap. off - Turn off Word Wrap.


TouchDesigner Build: Latest\nwikieditorwikieditor2022.24140before 2022.24140
DATs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

An Operator Family that manipulates text strings: multi-line text or tables. Multi-line text is often a python Script or GLSL Shader, but can be any multi-line text. Tables are rows and columns of cells, each containing a text string.



A Link. The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference or Link that indicates one operator is getting data from another operator from any Operator Family.


The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference (or Link). A Reference is (1) a Parameter Reference, a parameter in an OP that is a name or path to another operator, (2) a Node Reference, an expression in a parameter or DAT script that contains the name or path of another operator, (3) a DAT Cell Reference or (4) a CHOP Channel Reference.


A Link or Reference is a dashed line between nodes that represent other data flowing between nodes. Examples are CHOP Exports, node Paths in parameters, and expressions in parameters referencing CHOP channels, DAT tables and other nodes. In contrast is a Wire that connects nodes in the same Operator Family.



The generic thing that holds an Operator, and includes Flags (display, bypass, lock, render, immune) and its position/size in the network. Whether you "lay down an Operator" or "lay down an Node", you're doing the same thing.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=WebRTC_DAT&oldid=32308"
		Category: DATs
